properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heat continues tonight. Overnight lows in the upper teens to low twenties are expected for tonight, providing little relief from today's hot temperatures. A cooler airmass will arrive from the west on Thursday. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 11:37 p.m. CDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a severe thunderstorm capable of producing strong wind gusts, nickel to ping pong ball size hail and heavy rain. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Intense lightning is likely with any thunderstorm that develops. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.
Expires: 2020-06-18T07:06:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-18T04:37:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3298443913.2020
Area: R.M. of Brokenhead incl. Beausejour and Garson, Manigotagan Black River Res. and Hollow Water Res., Bissett, R.M. of Alexander incl. Powerview-Pine Falls, R.M. of Lac Du Bonnet
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts, large hail and heavy rain. Hazards: - Damaging wind gusts of 90 to 110 km/h - Quarter to ping pong ball size hail - Torrential downpours giving 50 mm rain in an hour or less - Risk of a tornado Locations: Portions of far Northern Ontario including Big Trout Lake, Webequie, Attawapiskat and Winisk River Provincial Park. Timing: Tonight ### Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Intense lightning is likely with any thunderstorm that develops. Heavy downpours are likely to cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm. For more information: http://www.emergencymanagementontario.ca/english/beprepared/beprepared.html.
Expires: 2020-06-18T14:59:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-18T02:12:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3565687526.2020
Area: Attawapiskat, Big Trout Lake - Kasabonika, Summer Beaver - Wunnummin Lake - Kingfisher Lake, Webequie, Fort Hope - Lansdowne House - Ogoki, Fort Albany
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 11:04 p.m. EDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a severe thunderstorm capable of producing very strong wind gusts, up to nickel size hail and heavy rain. This line of severe thunderstorms is located from 65 kilometres northeast of Missisa Lake to 9 kilometres south of Scharf Lake, moving south at 10 km/h. Locations impacted include: Fishtrap Lake and Missisa Lake. Hazards: 100 km/h wind gusts, nickel size hail, torrential downpours giving local rainfall amounts near 50 mm. Thunderstorms continue this evening into the overnight hours. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Intense lightning is likely with any thunderstorm that develops.
Expires: 2020-06-18T06:59:13-00:00

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 11:59 p.m. CDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a severe thunderstorm capable of producing very strong wind gusts, pea to dime size hail and heavy rain. A north to south line of thunderstorms has developed near the Ontario-Manitoba border and is moving slowly east into the area. Torrential downpours are likely, which will lead to rainfall amounts of 50 to 75 mm in areas that receive two or more thunderstorms in a row. Locally higher rainfall amounts of 75 to 100 mm are possible near the Manitoba Border tonight. Wind gusts to 100 km/h are also possible. ### Heavy downpours are likely to cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Intense lightning is likely with any thunderstorm that develops. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes.
Expires: 2020-06-18T08:29:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-18T05:00:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2424466226.2020

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 12:00 a.m. CDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a dangerous thunderstorm capable of producing strong wind gusts, pea to dime size hail and flooding rain. A slow moving line of thunderstorms moving northeastwards across southeastern Manitoba will bring torrential rainfall to the region. Localized rainfall accumulations in excess of 100 mm are possible. Gusty winds and hail are also possible with these thunderstorms. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Intense lightning is likely with any thunderstorm that develops. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.

properties.Title: Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Squalls with wind gusts up to 50 knots, frequent lightning, waterspout activity and poor to very poor visibility in thunderstorms heavy at times are expected or occurring in the area. A north to south line of severe thunderstorms will slowly move across the lake tonight. Squalls to 50 knots are possible. Visibility may suddenly be reduced to near zero in torrential downpours. Mariners should remain in port until the thunderstorms pass by. ### Keep in mind that waterspouts cannot be seen at night and may strike suddenly. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. For more information monitor Canadian Coast Guard radio or Weatheradio stations.
Expires: 2020-06-18T08:29:15-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-18T05:04:15-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2469012373.2020
Area: Lake of the Woods
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 9:20 p.m. CDT (10:20 p.m. EDT), Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a cluster of severe thunderstorms capable of producing very strong wind gusts and up to toonie size hail. This area of severe thunderstorms is located 10 kilometres east of Sakwaso Lake, moving east at 65 km/h. Hazards: 100 km/h wind gusts, torrential downpours producing 50 mm of rain in an hour or less, and 2 cm hail. Locations impacted include: Magiss Lake, Weagamow Lake, Weagamow Lake, Eberle Lake, Staunton Lake, Nikitowa Lake, De Blicquy Lake, Seeseep Lake, Cemetery Lake, North Caribou Lake, Schade Lake, Opapimiskan Lake, Skinner Lake, Wastayanipi Lake, Big Beaver House, Kingfisher Lake and Kingfisher Lake. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes.
Expires: 2020-06-18T06:14:55-00:00

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Temperatures reaching 27 degrees Celsius are expected. A prolonged period of above normal temperatures and high humidex values will continue in the Kugluktuk area tonight into Thursday before coming to an end by Friday. The overnight low for Kugluktuk tonight is forecast to be 15 degrees Celsius and Thursday's daytime high temperature will approach 27 degrees Celsius with a humidex of 29 degrees. The current record high temperature for Kugluktuk on June 18 is 26.7 degrees Celsius, set in 1935. Records for this area began in 1930. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-18T19:28:03-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-18T03:29:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3800766622.2020
Area: Kugluktuk
properties.Author: Environment Canada
